awd_titl_txt: IIBR: Development of enhanced computational protein design methods using a metaanalysis of enzyme dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
Proteins are biomolecules that carry out the cellular processes that are fundamental to life. It has recently become well-established that concerted motions (dynamics) within proteins are directly correlated to their function, but an incomplete understanding of this relationship currently exists. To further elucidate the link between protein dynamics and function, recently developed computational methods will be used to first identify and subsequently classify networks of interactions in proteins that are directly responsible for defining the motions that underpin their functions. Information regarding these networks will be organized in a database that will be made freely available to researchers interested in both studying protein function or rationally engineering proteins that possess desired functions. The potential utility of this database will then be directly tested by using the information contained therein to improve protein engineering efforts. Enhanced proteins generated using this database will be experimentally characterized in an effort to both validate and subsequently improve the information contained therein. This will not only lead to a deeper understanding of the relationship between protein dynamics and protein function but will also find immediate use in myriad biotechnological applications including the development of new protein-based drugs, enhanced agricultural products or the production of new, functional biomaterials. An enhanced understanding of the relationship between protein dynamics and function can also readily be incorporated into educational materials using a popular online protein folding game, FoldIt, which will be used in outreach activities that seek to inspire interest in STEM fields at the high school educational level.

The primary goals of the proposed research are 1) to better elucidate the complex relationship between protein dynamics and function and 2) to develop new computational protein design algorithms that enable the rational design of functional proteins from scratch. Our current understanding of the relationship between protein sequences, their structures and functions has benefitted substantially from the aggregation and dissemination of this information in publicly accessible databases. Although a direct link between correlated motions in proteins and the functions they carry out is well-established, no database of protein dynamics currently exists, which we believe severely limits our ability rationally engineer functional proteins. We will address this challenge by generating the first large-scale database of the dynamic signatures of proteins of known function and then cluster these data both within and across enzyme functional classes. Our findings will be incorporated into the Rosetta protein design software to develop dynamics-based computational protein design methods that will subsequently be used to engineer new dynamic networks within proteins. This will serve as a direct test of our understanding of the relationship between protein structure, dynamics and function. Experimental characterization of our designed proteins will serve to improve our computational methods and will further enhance our understanding of the interplay between dynamics and protein function. The long-term goal of this study will be to use the lessons learned in this study to generate cutting edge computational protein design tools that could be used to study enzyme function, enhance the catalytic efficiencies of existing designed enzymes and enable the de novo design of artificial enzymes with desired activities.Results of this project will be reported at 
https://sms.asu.edu/jeremy_mills and http://ozkanlab.physics.asu.edu/research.html.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Proteins are fundamental biomolecules that carry out some of the most important biological processes in all living organisms. Although constructed from only 20 simple building blocks (called amino acids), proteins can achieve incredibly complex functions. One class of proteins of particular importance are enzymes, which have the ability to catalyze difficult chemical reactions that are crucial to cellular function. The ability to rationally alter the function of enzymes could lead to advancements in many fields of science including the development of new treatments for disease; however, this represents a challenging goal. Namely, a protein’s function is defined by its three-dimensional structure, which is in turn defined by the order in which the amino acids that comprise the protein are connected to each other. Alteration of even a single amino acid can have profound effects on protein function. Because all enzymes are proteins, the ability to engineer enzymes with novel properties would necessitate a thorough understanding of the relationship between a protein’s sequence and its structure as well as the relationship between a protein’s structure and its function. Given the size of most proteins, which contain hundreds to thousands of linked amino acids, insights into the manner in which a protein’s structure defines its function are difficult to achieve.

 In recent years, computational protein design methods have been developed that provide pathways for the design of enzymes with new or altered functions. However, these methods frequently result in enzymes with efficiencies that are dramatically reduced relative to their naturally occurring counterparts. One potential explanation for this is the fact that proteins are not static entities. Rather, proteins (including enzymes) are constantly in motion, both jiggling subtly and (in some cases) swaying dramatically in ways that are defined by (and unique to) a particular structure. It is now well established that these motions likely have profound implications on protein function. Thus, efforts to rationally alter enzyme function must therefore pay heed to such “protein dynamics”; existing enzyme design methods do not do this.

In this work, we hoped to generate an enhanced understanding of the relationship between enzyme dynamics and function. To do this, we leveraged recently developed computational approaches that allow a flexibility profile of a protein to be rapidly determined. Although such methods have been previously used to relate the dynamics observed in enzymes to their functions, relatively few enzymes had been thoroughly considered in this manner. Thus, we began our study by developing a database of enzyme dynamics that was generated by deploying these methods on a large swath of enzymes with distinct, but important functions. Our large-scale characterization of the “dynamic signatures” of multiple enzymes elucidated similarities and differences in protein motions present within them. By curating these signatures within a single database, we hope to enable highly targeted studies that shed light on the complex relationship between protein motions and protein function. Our database is freely available to the public and can be found at https://dynamicsdb.org.

A second major focus of this work was to begin to explore hypotheses related to the relationship between protein dynamics and function that were generated using the aforementioned analytical methods. Namely, we generated flexibility profiles for an enzyme that is important in antibiotic resistance and then used these profiles to predict how mutations at specific sites would alter its function. We generated and experimentally characterized a number of variants of a protein called “TEM-1” that can degrade penicillin-like antibiotics. The primary goal of this study was to better understand the relationship between the dynamic signatures of TEM-1 variants and their ability to degrade antibiotics. Studies like this are directly enabled by our large-scale analysis of enzyme dynamics and could be extended to better understand the functions of other enzymes.

This grant supported a total of three graduate students and one postdoctoral fellow; two of the graduate students have been granted Ph.D. degrees. Additionally, a team of three high school students conducted work related to the goals of our project and competed at both local and international science fairs. Work supported by this grant was presented at multiple national scientific conferences and resulted in seven publications in peer reviewed journals.


Last Modified: 01/03/2024
Modified by: Jeremy H Mills
